title: 115_s256
content: The "SOAR to Health and Wellness Act of 2017" defines human trafficking and establishes a pilot program. The Secretary will establish a pilot program called "SOAR to Health and Wellness Training" to train healthcare providers on identifying and assisting potential human trafficking victims in compliance with legal requirements. The pilot program "SOAR to Health and Wellness Training" aims to train healthcare providers on identifying and assisting potential human trafficking victims by implementing proper protocols, providing coordinated and victim-centered care, and considering integration with existing training programs for victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The pilot program aims to address domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, stalking, child abuse, neglect, maltreatment, and sexual exploitation. It includes functions from the Stop, Observe, Ask, and Respond to Health and Wellness Training program and engages stakeholders to develop a flexible training module. The pilot program aims to address various forms of abuse and exploitation. It includes functions from the Stop, Observe, Ask, and Respond to Health and Wellness Training program and engages stakeholders to develop a flexible training module for diverse health care sites. Grants are available to support training in sites representing different demographics and types of human trafficking cases. Technical assistance is provided for nationwide health education programs. The pilot program, part of a nationwide health education initiative, aims to develop training materials and protocols for identifying and assisting human trafficking victims in healthcare settings. It also includes incentivizing the utilization of these materials and developing a methodology for data collection. The program is set to terminate on October 1, 2022. The pilot program focuses on developing training materials and protocols for identifying human trafficking victims in healthcare settings. It includes incentivizing material utilization and data collection methodology. During fiscal years 2019 through 2023, the Secretary will collect data on facilities and providers involved in the pilot program for identifying human trafficking victims in healthcare settings. This includes tracking the number of facilities operating under the program and the training of healthcare providers. The Secretary will collect data on facilities and providers involved in the Stop, Observe, Ask, and Respond to Health and Wellness Training program before the pilot program. A report must be submitted to Congress within 90 days after the start of fiscal years 2019 through 2023. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $3,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2018 to 2022.
